text: the Supreme Court on Thursday throughout
63 year old restrictions on campaign
spending the court said that companies
can spend as much as they like in
support of candidates for President and
Congress the court also ruled that
companies and unions can't be prohibited
from spending money from their own
Treasuries for campaign ads I spoke to
David Kirkpatrick and I asked him to
explain the implications of the ruling
well certainly the conventional wisdom
is that Republicans will be the big
winners here because the case opens the
the ability of corporations and unions
and other groups to spend money directly
to influence elections and Republicans
are closer to business but the caveats
there are that big companies actually
don't have that much appetite for
getting into messy combative elections
because it alienates other public
officials shareholders and their
customers so they could do it through
trade associations but the actual
political operatives say the big trade
associations you know Chamber of
Commerce they're not as effective
because they don't do the they have
their own brand name to protect so they
don't necessarily roll out that kind of
really mean a negative ad that a kind of
ad hoc group like swift boat veterans
for truth or move on org could come up
with so it's a little bit too soon to
tell whether the Republicans are really
going to be the big winners here or
could be more evenly divided David does
this mean campaign finance reform is
just dead well it's not good for the
whole project of campaign finance reform
because if you're you know the way to
look at it is if you could go through an
independent group and spend as much as
you want without limit to influence an
election why bother going through a
party or a candidate where your
contributions are severely limited their
fundraising is limited and there's a lot
of disclosure so in a way it makes the
the party puts the parties and
candidates at a disadvantage relative to
outside special interests now is there
anything that the Congress can do to
mitigate this ruling at all well they're
trying congressman Van Hollen in the
house and Senator Schumer and the Senate
are both introducing bills that they've
actually been working on for some time i
was told that at one point they had
seven different drafts of potential
remedies in the works so that once this
decision came down they could try to get
something done ahead of the midterms in
the fall that a real reestablishing
differ
some of the bands on corporate spending
for example any company that hires a
lobbyist might be restricted from how it
could independent spend money
independently to influence an election
if this ruling stands on there in
Congress is not able to do anything
before the midterms midterm elections
how might the midterm elections be
different than what we've seen in the
last few elections when these laws were
in place well the big difference is
going to be more negative advertising
because if you are an outside group and
no candidate has to take responsibility
for the ad then chances are you're going
to put your money towards a pretty mean
negative ad because that's more
effective and again nobody has to take
responsibility so it's likely to make
things certainly more negative than they
were in 2008 when the leaders of both
parties kind of said to their supporters
cool it down out there but even more
negative i would think than 2004 which
was a pretty ugly campaign in some ways
